title: Dry transfer font name?
content:
Anyone know the name of this font and if there is an equivalent of the digital font available?

The image was found within a search with google and the site that hosted that image was gone but somehow the image still available...

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414040753im_/http:/typophile.com/files/font_4552.jpeg)

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [font.jpeg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414040753/http:/typophile.com/files/font_0.jpeg) | 93.8 KB |
author: jch02140

comments.content:
Mesquite, apparently: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/willceau/3450731125/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414040753/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/willceau/3450731125/ "http://www.flickr.com/photos/willceau/3450731125/") (Found using Google's search by image.)

No-one in that thread has been able to spot a digital equivalent, unfortunately.

This appears in a 1980 VGC catalog as Mesquite. It's marked as a VGC original - although sometimes that proved to be a false claim.

I know of no digital version.
Thanks for identifying the font and the info. :)

So close to Bullion by Face Photosetting (distributed by Letraset), it hurts. [Nick Curtis did a revival of Bullion called Bully Pulpit, in shadow and plain variants.](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414040753/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/bully-pulpit-plain-nf/)

The type in question probably is a VGC original. Definitely seen it many times before.

According to my old Letraset Product Manual, Bullion Shadow was created by Face Photosetting.  
Don
